unnormalised: Someone asked me how much cement is required for constructing a small house in India. Well, it depends a lot on the plan. I helped my uncle build a 2BHK in his village near Pune. He initially estimated the built-up area to be around 1000 sq ft, but it ended up being closer to 1200 sq ft because of the verandah he added later. That extra 200 sq ft cost him in materials, especially cement!
normalised: Someone asked me how much cement is required for constructing a small house in India. Well, it depends a lot on the plan. I helped my uncle build a two B-H-K in his village near Pune. He initially estimated the built-up area to be around one thousand square feet, but it ended up being closer to one thousand two hundred square feet because of the verandah he added later. That extra two hundred square feet cost him in materials, especially cement!

unnormalised: For a typical house, you'll need cement for the foundation, the RCC (reinforced concrete) work like columns and beams, brickwork, and plastering. We used approximately 150 bags of cement, each weighing 50 kg, just for the RCC. Then another 80 bags for the brickwork and plastering. So, in total around 230 bags, or 11500 kgs of cement. He bought from a local shop, the price varied between Rs. 350 to Rs. 400 per bag depending on the brand and day.
normalised: For a typical house, you'll need cement for the foundation, the R-C-C (reinforced concrete) work like columns and beams, brickwork, and plastering. We used approximately one hundred and fifty bags of cement, each weighing fifty kilogram, just for the R-C-C. Then another eighty bags for the brickwork and plastering. So, in total around two hundred and thirty bags, or eleven thousand five hundred kilograms of cement. He bought from a local shop, the price varied between rupees three hundred and fifty to rupees four hundred per bag depending on the brand and day.

unnormalised: Of course, these are rough figures. It's always best to consult a civil engineer who can provide a more accurate estimate based on your specific design, soil conditions, and the type of construction you're planning. My uncle ended up buying an extra 20 bags, which he used later for some minor repairs and landscaping. Better to have a little extra than to run short in the middle of construction, bhai!
